results.title: The Ebony tower
results.creator_credit: Robert Knights, Roy Roberts, Granada International Productions and John Fowles
results.brief_description: An aging artist (Laurence Olivier) and his two young companions, “The Mouse” (Greta Scacchi) and “The Freak” (Toyah Willcox) find their idyllic life suddenly interrupted by the visit of a young art critic (Roger Rees). Based on the book by John Fowles with screenplay by John Mortimer.

results.title: The Director and the film: David Lean
results.creator_credit: Hazel Wilkinson and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: David Lean in a discussion with actress Maureen Pryor, comments on the aims and techniques he used in ‘The Sound Barrier’, ‘Brief Encounter’, ‘Bridge on the River Kwai’ and ‘Summer Madness’. (nb: A black and white film except for the extract from ‘Summer madness’ which is colour)

results.title: The Earth beneath me
results.brief_description: Follow Dick Smith as he travels solo around the world in his Bell Jetranger across some of the most inhospitable and lonely places in the world; the Arctic Circle; the deserts of Africa; the jungles of South East Asia. He also flies over some the world most famous landmarks; the Leaning Tower of Pisa, the Parthenon, Pyramids, Mount Everest, Taj Mahal and Australia’s own, Sydney Opera House. No other production details available. Warning; there are tracking problems at the start of the video and the image drops out during the end credits.

results.title: The Director [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Patrick Hughes and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: An ex crew member in witness protection recalls what it was like to work for “Jack” - the eponymous director of the title. The finely tuned professional outfit that is “the crew”, arrive at the Western Bank for a shoot, centred around the director, a man who wields awesome power and will do anything for the sake of realism and reaping the benefits at the box office.

results.title: The Diploma Disease (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Angela Little, Ron Dore and Institute of Development Studies
results.brief_description: Educational credentials are increasingly required by employees and so education gives way to ritualised preparation for exams. The ideals of education are powerless against the pressure on schools in societies which have caught the “diploma disease”. Examines symptoms in Japan, Mexico, Sri Lanka, and Britain

results.title: Testing and intelligence
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
How smart are you? Can the richness and complexity of intelligence be summed up in a number? and what is the effect of this number on you? In this program Philip Zimbardo looks at the controversial area of psychometrics, of cognitive, intelligence tests and psychological assessment tests. He introduces the different tests established by Binet, Galton, Wexler and others and stresses the extreme care that must be taken in administering and using the tests. He concludes by summarising the nature versus nurture argument which has been provoked by testing.

results.creator_credit: Fiona Cochrane, John R. Hipwell, Community Services Victoria, Film Victoria and HIPS Film and Video Productions

results.title: Sensation and Perception
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
Perception is our way of using our sensory apparatus to make contact with our environment. How does our brain recognise objects? In this program, Philip Zimbardo examines how we sense and perceive our environment, to process information and transform raw sensory data into meaningful impressions. He also discusses the way personal experience can influence our perceptions.

results.title: Nightride
results.creator_credit: Martin Murphy, Della Churchill and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A masked killer, a series of brutal murders, a confined space, a resourceful young hero and a terrifying confrontation. Nightride cleverly condenses the conventions of the horror film established in Halloween and Friday the 13th into a suspenseful 11 minute film.

results.title: The Eagle has landed [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: John Sturges, David Niven Jr, Jack Wiener and ITC Entertainment
results.brief_description: A Colonel with the Luftwaffe, imprisoned for striking a fellow officer, is offered a lifeline when Nazi Colonel Radl (Robert Duvall) asks him to lead a daring suicide mission to kidnap Winston Churchill. Radl has received direct orders from Heinrich Himmler (Donald Pleasance), who in turn, has been instructed by Hitler himself. The PM is known to be holidaying in Norfolk, so recently released prisoner Karl Steiner (Michael Caine) and his men parachute into Sudley Constable, a small village nearby, camouflaged as Polish allies. The sixteen man team comprises of a motley crew of stereotypes, including a honey voiced IRA man Liam Devlin (Donald Sutherland), who dupes a young girl on horseback (Jenny Agutter) - one of the few women in the film. After an incident in which one of his men saves the life of a local boy, their mission is jeopardised when the rescuer is killed and his Nazi identity revealed beneath the Polish garb. Steiner and his men take refuge in a Church as they await the arrival of Churchill to complete the Fuhrer’s orders. Based on the Jack Higgins novel, this was the last film John Sturges (The Great escape, The Magnificent seven) directed before his death in 1992. Cast also includes Anthony Quayle, Jean Marsh, Treat Williams and Larry Hagman. Screenplay by Tom Mankiewicz.
